Assuming ( on no very clear grounds ) that 485 is a significant year ing the fifth recurrence of an eighty - one year cycle from the Lycurgan reforms,  the author concludes »that there are fairly cogent reasons for dating the Lycurgan reforms to 809 B.  C.  «.  Readers who are less easily bewildered by such calculations than the reviewer will decide for selves whether there is not an argument in a circle to be detected here : and will look in vain for any hint that the social and political organisation implied by the Lycurgan reforms seems strangely mature for such an early date.  They may even ask whether the fact that the Spartans themselves apparently believed in this date is a fairly cogent reason for our accepting it. 
6. 
Chapter X »The Spartan Army Organisation and the Population Problem « is not easy to summarise,  partly owing to its inevitably statistical nature,  but also,  it must be admitted,  owing to its rather disjointed ment.  In the first place the author does not believe in a serious decline in the strength of the Spartan army between the Persian Wars and the date of Aristotle's Politics^ contending that the figure of 5000 given by Herodotus ( ix.  10 ) is not to be trusted,  and that Aristotle's »bare thousand« rests,  like it,  on the mistaken idea that Spartiatae meant the full strength of the hoplite force apart from the Perioeci and the Helots.  The view that the Spartiatae formed in fact only a portion of the citizen - levy is supported by Xenophon's figure of 6000 Spartan hoplites in the field at Corinth in 394,  but it is left undecided from what source the » non - Spartiate « contingents were drawn. 
The meaning of Lochos and Mora is re - examined,  with the conclusion that Xenophon's »twelve Lochoia in the period after Leuctra represent an innovation in the form of »double units« ( /.  <? .  in depth ),  a lesson learned from that disaster.  Two points which are effectively made are that the Spartan weakness in training and using cavalry was a serious drawback ; and that a gradual evolution can be traced through the fifth century from a heavy to a lighter hoplite equipment,  without a breast plate,  and with a shorter sword and a leather pilos replacing the bronze helmet.  The stone of Mnason from Thebes is temptingly identified,  in view of his equipment,  as that of a Spartan ( in spite of his moustache ) ; but that he may have fallen at the siege of Plataea is not very probable,  for the lettering might better suit a later date ( e.  g.  Haliartus or even Leuctra?  ).
